title: Consider PocketBase as alternative backend
description:
Evaluate and potentially implement PocketBase as an alternative backend layer.

## Why Consider
- Multi-device sync capability
- Web UI access alongside Electron
- Built-in admin dashboard
- Realtime subscriptions

## When to Revisit
- If multi-device sync becomes a requirement
- If web access is needed
- If self-hosted cloud backup is desired

## Implementation Approach
- Create PocketBaseAdapter implementing same repository interface
- Factory pattern to switch between Drizzle (local) and PocketBase (remote)
- Keep async interface (already prepared)

## Notes
- Not urgent - current local-only approach is fine
- Drizzle migration (async interface) prepares for this
- Revisit when use case emerges

title: Migrate storage layer to async + Drizzle ORM
description:
Migrate the storage layer to use async interface and Drizzle ORM.

## Goals
1. Change repository interface to async (Promise-based)
2. Adopt Drizzle ORM for type-safe schema and queries
3. Use drizzle-kit for migrations

## Scope
- Keep it simple, avoid over-abstraction
- If supporting both raw SQL and Drizzle causes too much complexity, just use Drizzle
- Can compare before/after via git history

## Tasks
- [ ] Install drizzle-orm and drizzle-kit
- [ ] Define schema in Drizzle format (watch_history, sync_meta)
- [ ] Update WatchHistoryRepository to async interface
- [ ] Migrate queries to Drizzle
- [ ] Setup drizzle-kit for migrations
- [ ] Update IPC handlers to work with async repository

## Notes
- better-sqlite3 driver works with Drizzle
- Drizzle is sync under the hood, but we wrap in async for future flexibility
- This prepares for potential PocketBase expansion later

title: Export Feature: JSONL export for backup and portability
description:
Add JSONL export feature for watch history data.

## Purpose
- Easy backup (single file copy)
- Human-readable format for inspection
- Portable data format for migration/sharing

## Features
- Export all watch history to JSONL file
- One JSON object per line (streaming-friendly)
- Include all fields from SQLite schema
- Optional: filter by date range

## Format
```jsonl
{"videoId":"abc123","title":"Video Title","channelName":"Channel","watchedAt":"2026-01-31T12:00:00Z",...}
{"videoId":"def456","title":"Another Video","channelName":"Other Channel","watchedAt":"2026-01-30T10:00:00Z",...}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Export function writes valid JSONL
- [ ] Handles large datasets (30k+ entries) efficiently
- [ ] Optional date range filter
- [ ] CLI or UI trigger for export

title: Local Storage: SQLite/JSON storage with deduplication
description:
Implement local data storage for watch history using SQLite.

## Storage
- **SQLite** with better-sqlite3 (synchronous, fast, no async overhead)

## Schema
```sql
CREATE TABLE watch_history (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
  video_id TEXT NOT NULL,
  title TEXT NOT NULL,
  channel_name TEXT,
  channel_url TEXT,
  watched_at TEXT NOT NULL,  -- ISO 8601
  thumbnail_url TEXT,
  video_url TEXT NOT NULL,
  is_ad INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
  source TEXT NOT NULL,  -- 'takeout' or 'playwright'
  created_at TEXT DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
  updated_at TEXT DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
  UNIQUE(video_id, watched_at)  -- deduplication
);

CREATE TABLE sync_meta (
  key TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  value TEXT
);
```

## Features
- Prevent duplicate entries (by video_id + watched_at)
- Track last sync timestamp in sync_meta
- Efficient querying for UI display (indexes on watched_at, title, channel_name)
- Support merging Takeout data with Playwright-scraped data

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] SQLite database with schema implemented
- [ ] CRUD operations for watch history entries
- [ ] Deduplication logic works correctly
- [ ] Last sync timestamp tracking
- [ ] Query support for search/filter (by date range, text search)
- [ ] Integration with existing parser module
close_reason: SQLite storage implemented with better-sqlite3. 30k entries insert in 111ms. Full CRUD, search, date filtering, sync metadata tracking.

title: Playwright Automation: Incremental history fetch from YouTube
description:
Implement Playwright browser automation to fetch watch history incrementally.

## Core Functionality
- Launch browser with persistent user data directory (maintain login state)
- Navigate to `youtube.com/feed/history`
- Fetch only new entries since last sync timestamp
- Handle infinite scroll to load more entries

## Requirements
- Persistent browser profile (user stays logged in across sessions)
- Stop fetching when reaching already-synced entries
- Handle page load states and dynamic content
- Graceful error handling (network issues, page changes)

## User Flow
1. User triggers sync (manual or scheduled)
2. Browser opens with persistent session
3. First time: user signs into YouTube manually
4. App navigates to history page
5. Scrolls and extracts until reaching last synced entry
6. Returns extracted data for storage

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Playwright launches with persistent user data
- [ ] Successfully navigates to YouTube history page
- [ ] User login session persists across app launches
- [ ] Incremental fetch stops at last synced entry
- [ ] Handles scroll loading for more entries
